doc.title: PHYML

description.text: A simple, fast, and accurate algorithm to estimate large phylogenies by maximum likelihood

doc.reference: Guindon, S. and Gascuel, O. (2003) A simple, fast and accurate algorithm to estimate large phylogenies by maximum likelihood Systematic Biology, 52(5), 696-704

interface.label: Data type (-d) DNA (nt) Amino-Acids (aa)

xhtml:div.label: Number of data sets to analyse (-n)

Number of bootstraps sets to generate (only works with one data set to analyse) (-b)?
b > 0: int is the number of bootstrap replicates.
b = 0: neither approximate likelihood ratio test nor bootstrap values are computed.
b = -1: approximate likelihood ratio test returning aLRT statistics.
b = -2: approximate likelihood ratio test returning Chi2-based parametric branch supports.
b = -4: (default) SH-like branch supports alone.
b = -5: approximate Bayes branch supports.
Nucleotide substitution model (-m) HKY85 JC69 K80 F81 F84 TN93 GTR
Amino-acid substitution model (-m) LG WAG JTT MtREV Dayhoff DCMut RtREV CpREV VT Blosum62 MtMam MtArt HIVw HIVb

xhtml:td.label:
predefined character frequencies?
Choose a character frequencies e m
e:
Nucleotide sequences: (Empirical) the equilibrium base frequencies are estimated by counting the occurence of the different bases in the alignment (default).
Amino-acid sequences: (Empirical) the equilibrium amino-acid frequencies are estimated by counting the occurence of the different amino-acids in the alignment.
m:
Nucleotide sequences: (ML) the equilibrium base frequencies are estimated using maximum likelihood.
Amino-acid sequences: (Model) the equilibrium amino-acid frequencies are estimated using the frequencies defined by the substitution model (default).

div.label: User character frequencies

div.style: overflow: visible; display: none; visibility: hidden;

div.div: only valid for nucleotide-based models. fA, fC, fG and fT are floating numbers that correspond to the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively.

xhtml:div.label: set transition/transversion ratio to get the maximum likelihood estimate (DNA sequences only) Yes No
User transition/transversion ratio for DNA sequences? (-t)
set proportion of invariable sites to get the maximum likelihood estimate. (-v) Yes No

User proportion of invariable sites? (-v)?
This option will not be took in account if "set proportion of invariable sites to get the maximum likelihood estimate" is switch on.
Number of relative substitution rate categories (-c)
set distribution of the gamma distribution shape parameter to get the maximum likelihood estimate Yes No

distribution of the gamma distribution shape parameter. (-a)?
Can be a fixed positive value.
This option will not be took into account if "set distribution of the gamma distribution shape parameter to get the maximum likelihood estimate" is switch on.

Tree topology search operation (-s)?
NNI SPR (a bit slower than NNI) BEST (best of NNI and SPR search)
PhyML proposes three different methods to estimate tree topologies. The default approach is to use simultaneous NNI. This option corresponds to the original PhyML algorithm. The second approach relies on subtree pruning and regrafting (SPR). It generally finds better tree topologies compared to NNI but is also significantly slower. The third approach, termed BEST, simply estimates the phylogeny using both methods and returns the best solution among the two.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The tree must be in Newick format.

xhtml:div.label:
parameter optimisation?
tree topology (t), branch length (l) and rate parameters (r) are optimised. tree topology and branch length are optimised. branch length and rate parameters are optimised. branch length are optimised. rate parameters are optimised. no parameter is optimised.
This option focuses on specific parameter optimisation.

sets the initial tree to random.?
Yes No
It is only valid if SPR searches are to be performed.

the number of initial random trees to be used.?
It is only valid if SPR searches are to be performed.
the seed used to initiate the random number generator (must be an integer)
Print the likelihood for each site in file. Yes No
Print each phylogeny explored during the tree search process in file. Yes No

ul.li: b > 0: int is the number of bootstrap replicates.
b = 0: neither approximate likelihood ratio test nor bootstrap values are computed.
b = -1: approximate likelihood ratio test returning aLRT statistics.
b = -2: approximate likelihood ratio test returning Chi2-based parametric branch supports.
b = -4: (default) SH-like branch supports alone.
b = -5: approximate Bayes branch supports.

e:
Nucleotide sequences: (Empirical) the equilibrium base frequencies are estimated by counting the occurence of the different bases in the alignment (default).
Amino-acid sequences: (Empirical) the equilibrium amino-acid frequencies are estimated by counting the occurence of the different amino-acids in the alignment.

m:
Nucleotide sequences: (ML) the equilibrium base frequencies are estimated using maximum likelihood.
Amino-acid sequences: (Model) the equilibrium amino-acid frequencies are estimated using the frequencies defined by the substitution model (default).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option will not be took in account if "set proportion of invariable sites to get the maximum likelihood estimate" is switch on.
Can be a fixed positive value.
This option will not be took into account if "set distribution of the gamma distribution shape parameter to get the maximum likelihood estimate" is switch on.

PhyML proposes three different methods to estimate tree topologies. The default approach is to use simultaneous NNI. This option corresponds to the original PhyML algorithm. The second approach relies on subtree pruning and regrafting (SPR). It generally finds better tree topologies compared to NNI but is also significantly slower. The third approach, termed BEST, simply estimates the phylogeny using both methods and returns the best solution among the two.
The tree must be in Newick format.
This option focuses on specific parameter optimisation.
It is only valid if SPR searches are to be performed.
It is only valid if SPR searches are to be performed.

b = -4: (default) SH-like branch supports alone.

format.code: ("", " -f %f,%f,%f,%f" % (a_freq, c_freq, g_freq, t_freq) )[a_freq is not None or c_freq is not None]

velem.label: BEST (best of NNI and SPR search)

comment.text: PhyML proposes three different methods to estimate tree topologies. The default approach is to use simultaneous NNI. This option corresponds to the original PhyML algorithm. The second approach relies on subtree pruning and regrafting (SPR). It generally finds better tree topologies compared to NNI but is also significantly slower. The third approach, termed BEST, simply estimates the phylogeny using both methods and returns the best solution among the two.

interface.label:
Tree topology search operation (-s)?
NNI SPR (a bit slower than NNI) BEST (best of NNI and SPR search)
PhyML proposes three different methods to estimate tree topologies. The default approach is to use simultaneous NNI. This option corresponds to the original PhyML algorithm. The second approach relies on subtree pruning and regrafting (SPR). It generally finds better tree topologies compared to NNI but is also significantly slower. The third approach, termed BEST, simply estimates the phylogeny using both methods and returns the best solution among the two.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: PhyML proposes three different methods to estimate tree topologies. The default approach is to use simultaneous NNI. This option corresponds to the original PhyML algorithm. The second approach relies on subtree pruning and regrafting (SPR). It generally finds better tree topologies compared to NNI but is also significantly slower. The third approach, termed BEST, simply estimates the phylogeny using both methods and returns the best solution among the two.
